questions.question: Which of the following documents is known as the Great Charter of Freedoms?

possible_answers.answer_text: The Charter of Rights and Freedoms

questions.quote: Together, these secure for Canadians an 800- year old tradition of ordered liberty, which dates back to the signing of **Magna Carta** in 1215 in England (also known as the Great Charter of Freedoms), including:

questions.question: Which rights are mentioned in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?

possible_answers.answer_text: Official Language Rights and Minority Language Educational Rights

questions.quote: The Charter attempts to summarize fundamental freedoms while also setting out additional rights. The most important of these include: **Mobility Rights — Canadians can live and work anywhere they choose in Canada**

questions.question: What is one of Canada's founding principles?
questions.quote: Obeying the law — **One of Canada’s founding principles is the rule of law**. Individuals and governments are regulated by laws and not by arbitrary actions. No person or group is above the law.

questions.question: What must Canadians be willing to do when called to do so?
questions.quote: Serving on a jury — **When called to do so, you are legally required to serve**. Serving on a jury is a privilege that makes the justice system work as it depends on impartial juries made up of citizens.

questions.question: Which of the following is a way to contribute to Canada?

possible_answers.answer_text: Serving in the regular Canadian Forces

questions.quote: There is no compulsory military service in Canada. However, **serving in the regular Canadian Forces (navy, army and air force) is a noble way to contribute to Canada** and an excellent career choice (www.forces.ca).
